title.narrative: KP- Spending Effectively for Enhanced Development

description.narrative: To improve the availability and management of public resources for delivery of primary, middle and high school education and primary health care services.

participating-org.narrative: Finance Department, Government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa

condition.narrative: By not later than three (3) months after the Effective Date, the Implementing Entity shall appoint a director of the SharedServices Unit, with qualifications and experience and under terms of reference satisfactory to the Association (Section I.D.2 ofthe Operation Agreement).

For purpose of verifying the achievement of the DLRs, the Recipient shall cause the Implementing Entity to engage, not later thansix (6) months after the Effective Date, an independent third-party entity or entities (the “Verification Agent”), withqualifications, experience and terms of reference satisfactory to the Association, to undertake the verification process (Schedule2, Section III.2 of the Financing Agreement).

The Implementing Entity shall, within three (3) months after the Effective Date, adopt the Program Implementation Manual as shallhave been approved by the Association and thereafter, implement the Program in accordance with the Program Implementation Manual(Section I.B.1.(b) of the Operation Agreement).

The Recipient shall cause the Implementing Entity to carry out the Program Action Plan in accordance with the schedule set out inthe said Program Action Plan in a manner satisfactory to the Association (Schedule 2, Section I.C.1 of the Financing Agreement).

The Recipient shall cause the Implementing Entity to establish, by not later than six (6) months after the Effective Date, andthereafter maintain, throughout the period of implementation of the Operation, a Program Steering Committee comprised of officialsof various government entities, in adequate numbers and under terms of reference satisfactory to the Association, vested with theresponsibility of overseeing the implementation of the Operation in their respective agencies (Schedule 2, Section I.B of theFinancing Agreement).

title.narrative: Multi-year budgeting implemented integrating development and current expenditure

baseline.value: Development and recurrent budgets not integrated and not multi year

target.value: Three-year indicative budgeting ceiling announced with the Integrated Budget Call Circular issued no later than March of thecurrent year

actual.value: Budget Call Circular for the financial year 2021-22 was issued on 14 December 2020. In this circular, three-year (2021-24)indicative budgeting ceiling was announced. 1On December 2021 the Government issues an integrated budget call circular for theFY 2022-23. The circular does not have a multi year perspective neither does it combine the recurrent and development ceiling.

title.narrative: Districts with completed audits within 90 days after the end of financial year
Repairs and maintenance expenditure ( % of development expenditure )
Automated budgeting and expenditure reporting systems

baseline.value: IFMIS coverage currently restricted only to Finance Department and CGA

target.value: FD deployed the automated billing process in at least 25 departments (cumulatively).

title.narrative: Composition of expenditure outturn compared to original approved budget (excluding Foreign Project Assistance)

actual.value: Expenditure outturn for FY 2021-22 for settled districts, is 7 percent.

title.narrative: Proportion of approved development budget for continuing projects in elementary and secondary education released within 90 days after budget approval
Districts that meet agreed KPIs for education and health service delivery

baseline.value: Education and health service delivery District Key Performance Indicators not notified.

target.value: Additional 5 districts meeting agreed KPI for delivery of education and health services. Total 35 districts meeting KPIs by the endof the program.

actual.value: 1. DOH notified province wise KPIs including NMDs and all of the KPIs data is reported through Independent Monitoring Unit(IMU).2. Education department has province wise approved KPIs and they collect all KPIs data through Education ManagementInformation System (EMIS).

title.narrative: Citizens surveyed on budget priorities and receiving budget information
PHC facilities having all the essential medicines and commodities
Availability of essential supplies in schools and hospitals and increased transparency

baseline.value: Delays in availability of essential medicine and school supplies.

target.value: (a) On average at least 80% of primary health care facilities have all the essential medicines for one year; and (b) At least 65%of primary, middle, and high school have all the essential supplies.

actual.value: a) According to IMU data 67% PHC facilities having all the essential medicines and commodities.b) 55% of schools has all theessential supplies

title.narrative: A costed medium term expenditure plan for primary, middle, and high school education and primary health care

baseline.value: KP does not have a costed MTEP for primary education and PHC.

target.value: Budget releases for non-salary recurrent budget lines, at least 20% of the approved budget for FY 26, per quarter, based on theminimum threshold set under DLR 1.1

actual.value: Preparation of MTEP in consultation with health and education is in progress.

title.narrative: Increased facility level responsibility for budgeting and spending in primary and middle schools and primary healthcare facilities

baseline.value: Limited facility level budget responsibility for primary health care centers and primary and middle schools ( non-salaryexpenditure up to PKR 3 million by Primary Teacher Councils).

target.value: (a) At least 75% of primary health care facilities manage own non-wage budget as per the approved policy in DLR 8.1 and maintain upto date books of accounts; and (b) At least 75% of primary and middle schools manage own non-wage budget as per the approved policyin DLR 8.1 and maintain up to date books of accounts.

actual.value: The activity is planned to be outsourced through Consulting Firm. The TORs are prepared to hire a consultancy firm for preparingthe framework.

baseline.value: Pension costs rising as a proportion of total revenue

target.value: FD has implemented parametric reforms to reduce the projected cost of pension benefits as a percentage of provincial own sourcefiscal revenues from a baseline estimate by additional 5% of projected own source fiscal revenues.

actual.value: Pension growth rate in last 3,4 years was 9% while in current fiscal years it is 7%. Finance Department has completed revision ofpension rules. Revised rules are submitted to cabinet for endorsement.

title.narrative: Increased recurrent expenditure for repairs and maintenance of public investment assets

baseline.value: Repairs and maintenance budget low and climate considerations not incorporated in physical assets

target.value: (a) FD has increased its repairs and maintenance recurrent expenditure by additional 1 percentage point; and (b) P&DD has published50% of completed PC IV reports on the department’s website.

actual.value: a) For FY 2020-21 R&M expenditure was 8,839,787,446 while for current FY it is 1,717,679,794 therefore, 1% decreased in R&Mexpenditure.b) PC-IV are not uploaded on P&DD website.

title.narrative: Primary, Middle and High schools and PHC facilities have functioning basic infrastructure

baseline.value: Several service delivery centers missing basic facilties.

target.value: (a) Additional 10% (45% in total) of primary, middle, and high schools are fully equipped with climate resilient basicinfrastructure; and (b) Additional 10% (45% in total) of primary health care facilities are equipped with climate resilient basicinfrastructure

actual.value: The GoKP has developed guidelines for climate resilience for primary, middle and high schools. Cabinet has approved the basicinfrastructure design for primary health centers. Actual work is yet to start in primary, middle and high schools.Cabinet hasapproved PHC facilities having functioning basic infrastructure design. 28% of PHC facilities are equipped with climate resilientbasic infrastructure.

title.narrative: Invoices paid directly into vendor bank accounts
Primary, middle, and high schools with filled teaching staff positions according to approved staffing norms
PHC facilities with filled medical staff positions according to approved staffing norms
of which, Maternal and Neonatal Clinics
